Article.ArticleTitle: Patterns of molecular genetic variation in Plantago major and P. intermedia in relation to ozone resistance.

AbstractText: Patterns of molecular genetic variation were examined in seed collections of Plantago major and Plantago intermedia, used previously to investigate the variations in ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ) resistance of these species across Europe. Total genomic DNA was amplified with random primers (random amplied polymorphic DNA (RAPD) and inter- single sequence repeats (SSR)) to produce 73 genetic markers. In addition, allozyme and chloroplast variations were surveyed. Genetic markers were examined for association with O<sub>3</sub> resistance in 18 British populations of P. major as well as 27 continental European populations of P. major and P. intermedia. Two populations that exhibited increased resistance to O<sub>3</sub> following several years' exposure to high O<sub>3</sub> concentrations in the field showed decreased genetic variation over time. In addition, their genetic composition showed no drastic change, which suggests that the change in resistance to O<sub>3</sub> was probably the result of selection on genotypes already present in local populations (selection in situ). It appears that selection for O<sub>3</sub> resistance may occur in independent populations, and also may involve a number of genetically determined traits. Consequently the finding that plants with similar degrees of O<sub>3</sub> resistance are not closely related was not unexpected. However, the finding of an association of several genetic markers with O<sub>3</sub> resistance merits further investigation.
